intro: Phyllanthus hamrur, commonly known as the Indian false dandelion, is a flowering plant belonging to the Euphorbiaceae family. It is a perennial shrub that typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in India and Southeast Asia. The plant features small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, and its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often hairy. Phyllanthus hamrur is also noted for its medicinal properties, with various parts of the plant used in traditional medicine for their anti-inflammatory and hepatoprotective effects. Its botanical characteristics make it an important species in both ecological and pharmacological contexts.
